App description:
Table Tennis Simulator
Hone your skills against our AI or with our minigames designed to help you improve, then see how you stack up against players from around the world!

Physics Engine
From the very start, we have been obsessed with creating the most realistic table tennis simulation the World has ever seen. After countless hours of hard work and support from our amazing community, we believe that we accomplished that goal. 

We hope that you enjoy playing Eleven as much as we enjoy working on it. If you run into any issues or if you're interested in joining our ever-growing community of table tennis fanatics, follow the link in the additional details section and join us on our discord.

deepthinkerMay 19 at 11:05 PM
Impressive but not realistic enough

I've been playing table tennis for a few years and consider myself intermediate amateur, and I've won a company tournament before. Don't have the space for a table at home. Tried racket fury before Eleven got ported to quest, and felt it way off from the real thing, the physics engine (the main factor I care of) was a total joke. Now Eleven is available, and I expect to be stuck at home for a long time due to covid-19, I would like to try it and was hoping to use it to keep my regular training.

After one hour of tweaking around paddle settings and playing against robot, not surprisingly it turned out to be much better than racket fury. Physics engine is way better and pretty tunable. The game is playable at least after some fine tuning. For beginners, this is a very good simulation fof the real thing, and might bring even more fun thanks to online matches with a pool of players of various skill levels. And it seems that the developer really cares about user feedback and keeps improving the game, this is a big plus. Bravo!

Now the issues (why only 4 stars):

1. I found it very easy to completely miss the hit (occasionally hit the edge of the paddle) when doing a fast swing like forehand fast top spin loop, even after I adjust the paddle grip to match my actual paddle grip (took me more than half an hour of fine tuning). Even smashing misses a lot so it's unlikely an issue with the angle of paddle setting. Slower loops and hits are a lot less likely to miss. I'm talking about playing with robot, so it's not internet latency issue. I guess it could be somewhat related to Quest's low 72Hz refresh rate (if the sensors sample with similar rate), but I think it could be compensated with algorithm in the physics engine, maybe something like better trajectory interpolation. This one is a deal breaker as I cannot play a serious game with only toy shots, and whenever I attack I miss the ball.

2. I couldn't do any of my regular serves. I customized the bounciness and spin and tried a lot of combinations, including max on both, but still couldn't serve over the net for a few of my serves. I use a good paddle (Butterfly innerforce layer alc, tenergy 05 & 80), and feels the paddle physics in the game just couldn't resemble the real paddle especially when serving long back spin or fast side spin, both would end up in the net with very low speed most of the time. I guess the physics engine here would need a large hand swing to create high speed, and wouldn't (or is not able to) honor a fast small swing and rotation which is very common when serving. Might also have something to do with the low refresh/sensor sampling rate, not sure. Almost a deal breaker.

3. A small bug: the game was fairly easy crashing after being adjusting the paddle grip for a few minutes. Nothing serious, just a bit annoying.

I gave it 4 stars for the great effort especially the physics engine, but that doesn't mean it works for me as a training tool or even a fun game to play. Without fixing or improving the 1 and 2 above, I would not spend much time playing it, since otherwise it might mess up my skills and feel in real table tennis.

hargisssFeb 29 at 10:37 AM
Eleven vs. Racket Fury.

Racket Fury inspired me to take up real table tennis, which in turn inspired me to buy Eleven. Which VR game is better? My impressions:
Gameplay: Eleven wins here. Racket Fury is arcade-like, organized into levels and opponents, and you unlock your way through the game. The early levels in Racket Fury are easy to beat because the robot opponents are programmed to make random dumb mistakes. You can play defensively and as long as you don't miss the table or fail to hit the ball you will win eventually against these 'rusty' robots.
Eleven is a simulation, and it means business. There are no points to score, no equipment to buy, and no need to progress through levels, the world is your oyster. If you wait for the AI to make a dumb mistake you're in for a very long game... even if the AI is with the difficulty set to 0. I like this because it challenges the beginner to think about offense from the start. You can't slide by on defense alone. Plus Eleven offers a few useful practice modes, like quadrants where you've got to control the ball. After just two days with Eleven, I saw a dramatic improvement in my real-life table tennis skills.
Eleven has lots of substance, but Racket Fury has style. Racket fury doesn't feel cobbled together. Its sci-fi aesthetic has coherent themes and all its assets are custom made. The opponents are brought to life through motion capture data,
and they seem less like robots than the AI opponents in 11, even though the opponents in RF look like robots. 11 has more bugs than RF too. I think I encountered some bugs in multiplayer, which infuriated my opponent.
Despite these flaws, Eleven offers real substance. If I had to pick one to play I would choose Eleven without hesitation.

Developer Response19 days ago

hello ansonort. If you enjoy the physics in Racket Fury, there is nothing Eleven can ever really do for you. The physics are completely different to the extent that people generally are not able to switch between the two without huge adjustment periods. (maybe you can) Any inconsistencies that you have observed are due to tracking issues. When tracked, the results will be the same every time. RF has a lot of assists in that department, even in simulation mode - but that is just a choice that dev made, and there are definitely users more happy with something that makes them feel like they are playing table tennis, even if they aren't quite doing so. We are working with oculus to improve the tracking and we may be able to completely remove tracking irregularities soon - but until then, the hardware limitation, mixed with the no-assist simulation game play, will result in the experience you have (when your tracking environment is sub par for whatever reason) Stop by the discord, i'll be happy to discuss in more detail me:carrotstien discord: https://tiny.cc/vr11

Developer ResponseJul 6 at 10:04 PM

hello kwatts. Because we are a very small team, and because we are trying to work as fast as we can, we can't spend enough time communicating through the game every single change. If you join the discord, whose link can be found in the left panel of the default menu, you'll see a notification channel that describes exactly what changes in each version. Because oculus platform is messing up the position of the tracking space, we have decoupled the position of the table from the tracking space. Instead, it is coupled to the gaurdian. This mean, that you should only need to set it once, and then as long as you don't update your guardian, it will stay exactly where you left it. Part of this, is to remove the ability for oculus to recenter or reset anything from their side. This means, holding down the oculus button does nothing. Instead, as the game tutorial suggests, use the B/Y buttons (press and hold) to achieve the expected result. Please join the discord so you can be up to date :) me:carrotstien discord: https://tiny.cc/vr11

Capt_Quint620Apr 19 at 12:49 PM
Pretty Legit Table Tennis Simulator

I am not an amazing table tennis player, but I know fundamentals and compete recreationally. I also was on board for the beta and it seems like some physics have improved quite a bit since. Example: I couldn't use my tomahawk serve well in beta, but that seems fixed...as well as other serves. So nicely done there.

I didn't necessarily get this for multiplayer, but the lobby looks busy and I got a lot of requests to play. Multiplayer play may need some improvement though. I thought I could read my opponents' moves but what looked like a huge miss-hit turned into a smash-like return on my side. I also am pretty sure the game didn't register some points I should've got for a double bounce on the opponent's side of the table. In other words, they were still able to hit a dead ball.

It takes some getting used to because it is VR and not real world, but if I shank the ball, I am sure it is my fault and not the game's. In other words, as a simulation, this seems on par with real physics. The ball machine will be my training tool since I am in an apartment and need to practice my strokes while in quarantine.

In summary, this game is a lot of fun for those not needing an arcade unrealistic experience. If you want to play for real, this game supersedes any other table tennis game I've played. I hope the developers continue to improve multiplayer experience and add content for solo playing. E.g. tournaments. Then I think you would really blow the other competition away.

Table tennis has been a top 5 sport, in the world, and I don't see why this couldn't be the best sport VR experience, in time.

Conclusion: get it. It is worth 20 dollars.

If you like table tennis, you will like this game.

hi Spongiform. We try so hard to let the user know how to reach us. A negative review is not the best way to reach us - it is pretty much extortion. We are very very available to help troubleshoot any issues you may have. The tutorial in the game explains how to position the table. The tutorial in the game does not mention anything about pressing the oculus system button to recenter. The oculus platform recentering process has caused a lot of issues for players so we have decoupled it from the game. The recenter now, please follow the instructions in the tutorial: stand where you want to stand, face where you want to face, and press and hold the room button (y/b). Within menu->settings->table settings, there is also a way to set the floor. Additionally, there are ways to enable draggable positioning. SoulnightFeb 28 at 12:39 AM
Train your real life TT skills in VR!!

I always had a love for table tennis.

So when I got my Quest last year, the first game I bought was Racket Fury. I was impressed at first. But was frustrated with multiplayer with the ball slowing down to adjust to strange high ping. Anyway, playing a lot of Racket fury and getting very good at it, I thought I was making progress in my real life game with racket fury, so I went to play in real life and it actually had made me much worse!

Then I heard of the beta of Eleven Table Tennis on Quest and gave it a shot. What a difference! The physics felt so realistic!! My real life serves worked directly in Eleven when I struggled to do them in Racket Fury...
So this time again I thought I was making progress in my real life game... So I did the real life test again and everything I learned translated, new serves, new way of playing with a lot of spin, etc... and the best proof is that I am now beating a friend I could never beat before, despite having solely trained in VR!

As far as multiplayer is concerned, Eleven is excellent because you generally get very low latency due to the use of p2p technology ( instead of using relays like racket fury does). So you end up being able to play with anyone around the world. I live in Germany and regularly play with people from the UK, France with very low ping ~25ms to 35ms ... but I also play with people in the USA with ~115ms ping and the game is rock stable.

Also, Table tennis is even more fun in VR because you you can try any kind of strokes and... are not running after the balls :-) You have various AI to train with and most and foremost, you have what feels like an infinite pool of talented player online with various styles that you will not even find in your local table tennis club. And bonus, you get to chat with anybody who did not mute his mic and makes a new VR table tennis friend.

Finally, 11TT creator "carrostien" is passionnated and works every day to further improve the game!

See you in game / Soulnight

samxrApr 9 at 2:04 AM
SO FUN! Good worldwide network play!

Love this game! Not a huge ping pong fan, but decent when I play.

Was having trouble at first. Especially with serving. It took me a couple of matches before I could score well against the easy AI opponent. Didnt realize I was serving too far forward.

Then my friend (ACROSS THE freaking WORLD) who told me to get this, wanted to play, and thats when the fun began!

Can you believe we were playing VR ping pong in real-time between Canada and New Zealand??

There were problems in the lobby trying to find us as friends in the Friends List. It wasnt showing up even though we were connected via Social in the Quest. We had to go to the Everybody List and wait a while to find each other in the list. It took a long time to refresh.

I was worried, because it only showed 1 red bar to his name, and there was only some other stranger with 3 yellow bars, and everyone else was 1 red bar - nobody with green bars. But I sent a challenge anyway and it worked! We had an average ping of 200-230ms which isnt great but we tried anyway. And guess what?? It was still awesome! Some help with what ping offset is might be nice we didnt try that as it seemed like that would add more delay? There were glitches however. Like double bounces on opponents side and then they suddenly hit it back.

I assume theres a ton of prediction going on on what to display for your opponent when theres latency. This could be fixed up I hope!! The other big thing that will help if you play this ACROSS THE WORLD, is if, during a heated match, you avoid looking at your opponents head or paddle, and keep your eyes on the ball only that will help. Otherwise you think theyre going to hit it one way, and you get surprised by the ball hit somewhere else. When things get heated with latency in the mix, try and pretend that the only accurate position is from the net to you. Try and ignore their side of the table a bit. So once you hit it over to your opponent, keep your eye on the ball and look for it coming back from the net to be able to play well.

Overall Its still very fun, and super low friction to get playing. Dont fully get the table positioning mechanic. It works sometimes?

The one, vaguely stereotypical song gets annoying. Please give options for other music. I like that the ball hit sounds different when its hits the couch or tv, or rolls. The TV scoreboard is nice, but Id like an option for a voice announcer (ideally as a friend that talks rather than a sports announcer type). Also strong haptics when you hit the ball and a louder sound emanating from your paddle hit would be better.

Also at end of a game, it moves on too fast and if it was a close game you dont know who won as it cleared the tv scoreboard too fast. You obviously can find out if you hit the menu button, but some celebratory sounds or animation would be nice.

I was worried this would be like a lame Wii ping pong game, but its soooo much better and very close to the real thing with the physics!

But once you get into this game, its SO REAL that you gotta be careful!! I almost leaned on the table a few times while playing and almost fell through to the floor. Also Im super paranoid about diving for long shots and watching my Guardian boundaries when going for tough hits.

I totally recommend Eleven!! Cant wait to see updates, and play more international table tennis with my friends!

Great Game with a couple flaws

This game is absolutely amazing, and definitely the best VR table tennis game on the market. Although this game is great, it is not without its flaws. Just as a P.S., I play club level table tennis in real life so these grievances are going to be from the perspective of an actual competitive player.
- First off, the bot. The bot puts an insane amount of side spin on the ball for the stroke it does. It's completely unrealistic. There is also little to no curve before the ball hits the table, so there is no tell as to how much side spin is on the ball. Either the stroke has to be made more obvious, the stroke has to be fixed, or make it curve more in the air. I suggest fixing the stroke of the bot by making it emulate some professional European players.
- When the bot switches between forehand and backhand sides, the bot completely switches hands. It is doing a forehand stroke on both sides. If you fix it, you should also allow players to choose between right-handed bot and left-handed bot.
- It feels like the bot is not affected by the sidespin I put on my serves at all. Even when I put heavy spin on the ball (and I'm on the max spin setting), it bounces off the bot's paddle like it has no spin.
- Add a timer between the end of a point and when a player can serve. Too many times have lost a point right after the previous point when I'm halfway across my room. I suggest around 4-5 seconds and maybe making it optional in settings

- Opening menu after getting a notification should open directly to notification screen. Way too annoying to click on the tiny icon every time.
- Laser pointer should default to non-dominant hand after a match (I play penhold, so it's awkward choosing with the same hand).
- Adding a filter to only get match invites from players that are only above a certain rating
- Maybe enfore 16cm toss more, but casual players might not like it
Despite these flaws, it's still a great game!

OtherbitsMar 1 at 3:21 AM
A good start

It certainly feel like a lot of effort has gone into the physics simulation for this game. Its been a long time since I played in real life, but I could mostly rely on muscle memory. The only complaint I and others had was that the racket wasn't where we instinctively thought it was, making us miss shots that we felt like we should have hit. Hard to say exactly why that's the case, and it didn't take long to get used to, but its worth noting. Aside from that, I can't fault the accuracy at all.

However this loses a star because clearly so much time has gone into the simulation that very little has been left over for the actual gameplay. The only single player modes are 3 very basic mini games, and a quick match against the AI. There's no campaign, objectives, or variation of any kind. The AI also seriously needs work, as the developer has acknowledged. It doesn't behave like a normal person. Fast balls stump it constantly while no other kind of tricky shot seems to phase it at all. It seems to know exactly how to move in order to hit the ball perfectly, and just randomly flubs the shot based on its skill level and the balls speed. You can perfectly predict whether your shot will land on the table based on whether the AI even moves. The menu system also feels very early-access.

Despite all of that, I have come back to this one quite frequently since buying it, simply because its quick to get into and satisfying to play. This isn't a game that holds your hand. If you've not played much table tennis, it will take practice to even reliably hit the ball back onto the table. And there's something addictive about that. It doesn't feel like you're playing a game at all. It feels like you're playing actual table tennis.

obi2kenobiMar 2 at 4:54 PM
The "Thrill of the Fight" of ping pong

This is like the "thrill of the fight" of ping pong. Just a straight up sim with no artificial garbage. Incredibly realistic physics, feels like playing with a legit $50 paddle. I played this in front of my bed which was awesome because when I had to dive for a ball i land on soft mattress :D

I also own Racket Fury and this blows it out of the water in my opinion.

I've never seen multiplayer so well done in VR. Typically VR multiplayer experiences are frustrating and slow and you wait around a lot. I found matchmaking to be quick and painless here.

In 11TT you can join a lobby and either send someone a challenge or wait for someone else to challenge you. When someone invites you a bell rings and you see a notification, which you can accept to play the match. Also, when you browse opponents it sorts them by "connectivity" so you know essentially if your match will be lag free or not (even shows you the ping). I would recommend against playing someone with bad ping/connectivity, as the one laggy match I had was a bit jarring/uncomfortable.

There are a few fun single player features as well, including a great AI and some mini games (which can be played while you wait in the MP lobby), but as long as multiplayer is this crowded they may not see much use for awhile!

XTC_91Mar 1 at 2:24 PM
Physics almost on point, menus are awful

Back in the days i've played table tennis in the club for a few years and still love to play from time to time. I think table tennis vr is some of the most immersive experiences you can have in VR but that also means the physics have to be on point.
Racket Fury and Eleven are both surprisingly good physics wise. You have to get used to it but after a few hours it feels natural, that already is a great accomplishment.

From a simulation perspective I like Eleven a bit better, less arcady and less buggy online so far.

Here are the issues I have so far in gameplay:

- High balls which are considered a 100% in real life way too often go wide after a smash
- Tracking issues on forehand while performing a top spin without looking at the ball
- Hard to get the right angle for a backhand topspin on a lower ball, way too often lands in the net
- missing the ball (especially forehand), ball flies through paddle

If those issues could get fixed we have the perfect table tennis simulator!

And for the love of god, please work on the ugly menus and the overall presentation. It took me a while to understand how to save presets or how to play online. In this area Racket Fury looks way more polished. Also the language translation to german needs to be improved big time, just get a native speaking person instead of google translator :)

But still the game is fun and i will definitely I will put in some practise into it!

Keep it up guys!

This is a great game!!!!! I've played a lot of racket fury (simulation mode) and it took a little while while to get adjusted to this game's feel. Now that I've become accustomed to Eleven's gameplay, I really like the overall physics of the game. This game is a much more accurate replica of the real thing. The feel and sound of the ball hitting the paddle and bouncing off the table are perfect. Where this game shines even more is in the environmental details. The room you play in is completely believable unlike racket fury's. The layout and the way things are arranged gives it a truly lived in feel. What's more impressive are the smaller details like the shadows made by the ball and paddle on the floor and table.

The reason I didn't give 5 stars is due to a few minor issues that I think are fixable.

While the sound made by the ball hitting the table is great, the way it flies and bounces with spin can be exaggerated. This issue increases with the amount of spin applied and the length of the rally. Another thing that would help the overall gameplay is to give the user more custom adjustments to the way the paddle reacts to the ball. The options presently available might be enough if the range from min to max was increased. Finally, adding a customizable play list would be cool,too.

Regarding each of your comments: 1. we aren't setting single player in any less importance than multiplayer. The current AI is stopgap, and even so, is very complex. To say that we don't care, considering how much work was done on the AI, is unfair. 2. regarding the environment: the desert, museum, old winter, are environment from the previous version of the game. They were terribly underperforming for quest so we removed them as part of the revamp. The new game supposed to have the studio environment, and the chalet (mountain top wintery place you mentioned). Unfortunately, oculus quest is pretty finicky and was crashing for some users. We have temporarily removed that environment and are planning to bring it back today (along with a buuunch of changes). If you'd like to have it immediately, I'll be more than happy to give you an offline version of the game that has both environments. 3. Regarding how the studio environment looks...you can't please them all i guess. Some people want it neater, some people want it to look lived in. 4. Regarding the ai appearance. We were banking on Oculus finishing the oculus avatar to the point where users would be able to pick and choose what they look like however they want. Unfortunately, this hasn't happened, and the other masks you see, are a temporary option just to give additional variety for online presence (oh yea, and some avatars break the game for OTHER users...which is why we had to put in the masks). HAS LOTS OF POTENTIAL, BUT REFUNDED

Eleven Table Tennis is the best table tennis experience you can get in Virtual Reality. Its physics are unrivalled and its player base ranges from amateurs to professionals, all looking to either compete or teach you if youre new to the sport.

The ball and racket react the same way they would in real life, and without cables its a fantastic experience. Being able to chat with your opponent brings a social aspect as well which is very nice.

I have been playing Eleven for a long time on steam with a PCVR kit and was excited to see it on the Quest store.

A lot of what is in the PC version is there and the graphics took only a small hit. The 30hz difference between my PCVR kit and the Quest does make it a bit more difficult to follow the ball however.

Those are all the great things i have to say about Eleven. If youre an old pro or someone whos never played before youll find fun in this game EXCEPT:

Wait. This game has a game breaking bug. Sometimes in multiplayer your serves will not go through and thus the opponent will score every time.

Im experienced in Table Tennis, i know how to play and how to serve properly. My serves are NOT FAULTY. Yet the game considers them faults and i lose a point each time it is my turn to serve. For now, until this problem is solved, i will be refunding this game.

fruiMar 24 at 3:40 AM
Realistc physics, gameplay needs work

Update 2: I have added one star to my original three star score which I now consider to be too harsh. Still I wish the gameplay could be improved. The physics is very real, but realism doesn't translate directly into fun. You can realistically emulate a world champion, but it will not be fun to play with him. You need to accustom to all level of players and let the game flow.

Update: Yes the physics is spot on. What I am complaining is the playing style. The AI is too much a chopper that is chopping all the time and the ball from the AI is spinning too much and too often. This is not the case in real life. I have been playing Ping Pong for over 40 years. Players don't do so much chopping either in professional or amateur games. In professional tournament it's not effective against strong players. In amateur play it can be fun for a while but too much chopping will spoil the flow and decrease the fun. Maybe you can add more chopping behavior above "Advance" level. At least for intermediate players too much chopping from the AI can be very annoying even if the physics is accurate.

I have been playing the Steam version for several years and I really love it. The Quest version has kept the realistic physics, but it has some downside as regards gameplay. The most negative change: the AI now hits the ball with too much spin, and this makes the direction of the ball very hard to predict, and the game much more frustrating and less fun. The AI makes a lot of spin even at the "Normal" difficulty setting. In reality there isn't so much spin, and the player can judge the direction of the spin according to the opponent's hand movement so as to make preparation in advance, but in ETT this prediction is not possible as the AI doesn't make any chopping movements. So I suggest decreasing the spin from AI. Of course it would be great if there is an option to adjust the playing style of AI (how much spin, smash, etc.), but for now simply decreasing the spin from AI is enough.
